subject: statistics
title: Confidence Intervals for Differences
contentHtml:
When comparing two means or proportions in a paired dataset, we often want to quantify the uncertainty of our estimate.

This formula provides a way to construct a confidence interval (CI) for the difference between these two values.
name: Two-sample difference CI" },
problemHtml: Suppose we want to compare the average scores of two groups, each with n=10 students. We have a paired dataset and want to construct a 95% CI for the difference in means.
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Calculate the mean differences", "mathHtml": "\( \bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2 = 3.5 \)", "explanation": "We first calculate the mean difference."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Calculate the standard error", "mathHtml": "\( s_p \sqrt{\frac{1}{n_1} + \frac{1}{n_2}} = 0.7 \)", "explanation": "Next, we calculate the standard error of the mean difference."}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Determine the critical t-value", "mathHtml": "\( t^{*-1} = 1.96 \)", "explanation": "We then look up the critical t-value for our desired confidence level (95%) and degrees of freedom (n-2)."} ],
intuition: This formula provides a way to quantify the uncertainty in estimating the difference between two means or proportions in a paired dataset.

title: Confidence Intervals for Differences
contentHtml: When comparing two means or proportions, it's essential to quantify the uncertainty in our estimates. This formula provides a way to construct confidence intervals (CIs) for differences.
name: Two-sample CI for differences" },
problemHtml: Suppose we want to compare the average scores of two groups, each with n = 30 students. The sample means are 75 and 80, respectively, with standard deviations 5 and 3.
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Calculate the difference in sample means", "mathHtml": "\(\bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2 = 75 - 80 = -5\)"}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Calculate the standard error of the difference", "mathHtml": "\(\sqrt{\frac{s_1^2}{n_1} + \frac{s_2^2}{n_2}} = \sqrt{\frac{5^2}{30} + \frac{3^2}{30}} = 1.08\)"}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Determine the critical t-value", "mathHtml": "\(t^* = 2.04 (for a 95% CI and n_1 = n_2 = 30)\)"}, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Construct the CI", "mathHtml": "\(\text{CI} = -5 \pm 2.04 \cdot 1.08 = [-8.12, -1.88]\)"} ],
intuition: This formula helps us quantify the uncertainty in our estimate of the difference between two means or proportions.
